body:
Hi @rudimk 

Docker for isolating kernel are things we did consider. Though, it would be putting a vault door 
on a house without wall. Most of the **real** security issues on the notebook are on the network side with notebook, not on the kernel side. 

To answer your other question, yes it is possible to launch a docker container as a kernel with current arch, you just have to configure `KernelManager.kernel_cmd` that can launch any program that can act as a kernel. I agree that auth is slightly more difficult but you shouldn't need a full wrapper around the notebook.

I can speek of some more detail in public, but those are things I like to avoid (don't want to give bad ideas to people). You can contact any of us in private for more details.

Hi, welcome!

At this point, the security/user model we are planing on using for the
multiuser notebook is that of the Unix user model. Having a notebook will
be equivalent to having a shell account. With this model, the goal is to
simply provide each notebook user with access to the files and process
space they have in their Unix account. This model assumes that all users
are trusted. Sure, someone could build a multiuser notebook server (Wakari
for example) that works with untrusted users. But the multiuser notebook
server that we ship with IPython, won't for now be that. In this context, I
am not sure that there is any real benefit in using Docker.

At the same time, I am following Docker very closely to see if/how/when it
makes sense to start to use it. I am pretty sure that at some point we will
use it. Docker is extremely powerful and a really great tool for this type
of thing. So no, I don't think this is crazy to think about at all. But we
want to start with the simpler trusted user, non-sandboxed usage case first
and see how that goes.

But, most of the infrastructure of the multiuser notebook server will be
the same regardless. We need to build a nice proxy that can forward
requests to individual notebook servers for each user. We need to build the
sharing UI, etc. that allows users to share their notebook with each other
and the public. We need to think more about user accounts, auth, security,
etc. We will be starting on this stuff later in the Spring, if you are
interested in helping out please keep in touch.

Cheers,

Brian

On Sun, Feb 9, 2014 at 10:25 AM, Rudi MK notifications@github.com wrote:

> Hello!
> I'm relatively unknown here, but I'll still go for my pitch. I've been
> using the IPython Notebook for ages, and my current startup - it's about
> computational math on the cloud - we use IPython a lot. We use Docker to
> spin up ad-hoc Linux containers - a user can create a container, specify
> memory limits and so on, and our platform spins it up, with things like
> IPython, numpy, octave installed. The containers are essentially sandboxes,
> and are isolated from one another.
> 
> It just struck me - Summer 2014's going to be all about the multi-user
> notebook. Do you think it's a long shot to think about using Docker to
> achieve that? The idea is that the notebook server runs as root, and every
> user(the notebook server user, not a Linux user) gets a container to work
> on. I don't think that can be worked into the existing notebook - so, we go
> ahead and build a wrapper app around it, that handles user auth, and
> container creation.
> 
> Would love to work on the details further, if you guys think it makes
> sense.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/5080
> .

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

Hello!

I think going for the Unix model right now, does make sense. Our approach
using Docker for MathHarbor is actually a lot of code that's been plugged
together to create sandboxes. BTW, our platform should be up pretty soon,
and I'd be grateful for your inputs!
Apart from that, I'd love to contribute, come spring, to work on auth and
maybe the proxy too.

Btw - Wakari uses containers too, for multi-user notebooks. OpenVZ
containers, which I personally feel aren't as easy to use or stable in
terms of disk usage, as compared to Docker.

You could join one of our dev meeting on Thurstday at 10 PST if you like to discuss once 3.0 is on the rails. 

I'm curious on how you handle security on the browser and side also, as isolating the kernels is only part of the equation.

Great, as we start to work on it we will post here to gather folks together.

Cheers,

Brian

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

@Brian - Super.

@Matthias - On the browser end, the biggest challenge we faced was with
port numbers. When you spin a Docker container, you have to expose a port
on the container to the host; a random port on the host is then bridged-up
to the port on the container. So, I run a Notebook server on port 5000 on
the container, and port 43567 is mapped to the Notebook server. To access
the notebook, I'd have to go to platform.mathharbor.com:43567, which was a
glaring loophole. We fixed that by using hipache - it's a rather neat load
balancer and proxy written by the folks behind Docker. We take the
container's hostname, create a subdomain - <container-hostname>.
platform.mathharbor.com, and push a key containing this sub domain and the
port for the container in question, into Redis. Hipache then reads the key
stored there, and proxies requests for such sub domains, to the appropriate
Notebook servers. Apart from that, I haven't really looked into other
possible vulnerabilities - I'd get started on that right away.

And yes, I'd love to join the dev meet. It's a Hangout on Air, right?

Ha, hipache, great, I wasn't aware of it. We were considering maybe writing something alike using node also. 

Yes hangout on air and agenda [on hackpad](https://hackpad.com/2014-IPython-Weekly-Development-Meetings-v8bNV6EmqVd) .

Hipache works really well. Scales pretty well, too. And it's in node. I'd
say, if we need similar functionality, which I reckon we do, Hipache's the
best bet. Haven't checked the licensing part, though.

> Docker for isolating kernel are things we did consider. Though, it would be putting a vault door 
> on a house without wall. Most of the real security issues on the notebook are on the network side with notebook, not on the kernel side.

Spot on @Carreau 

The real utility in putting kernels in Docker would be to be able to spin up jobs (through kernels) on some large set of machines, without having to manage the infrastructure (someone provides the layer above this) for deploying these.

We should point out that there are existing projects that use docker for multiuser notebooks, such as jiffylab and ipydra. Part of the reason we're planning our own multiuser server is to use the 'notebook user is system user' model, which I don't think there's anything for at present.

I've played with jiffylab and ipydra. Jiffylab is great for starters -
doesn't work so well if you try and scale it, it's meant for classrooms.
IPydra - same stuff. I think your approach of the notebook user being a
system user is great - and, to paraphrase, there's nothing like that at
present. I'm not well-versed with the nitty-gritties of Unix
authentication, but I feel it won't scale much, would it? Say, a thousand
users..the server itself might not be able to take it. But I went through
the roadmap, and I know this isn't something we're working on right now.
Just sayin'.

@Kyle - that's a great idea to test out with. Spin up containers on the
fly, for jobs. I've built "clusters" with containers, and they work pretty
well. I might have a go at what you suggested too.

> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/5080#issuecomment-34597304
> > .

> I feel it won't scale much, would it?

No, and it is not intended to. Scaling to large numbers of users is out of
scope for IPython itself. Scaling IPython deployments is possible, but that
work belongs in third party projects, which would need substantial
customization of kernel management, and possibly rewriting much of the
webapp itself.

-MinRK

I tried playing with jupyterhub - not sure how sharing containers for
collaboration is going to work. But yes, might as well close this issue.
